hints.content: Start by understanding what a self-divisible number is. A number is self-divisible if it can be divided by each of its digits without leaving a remainder. For example, 128 is self-divisible because 128 % 1 == 0, 128 % 2 == 0, and 128 % 8 == 0.
Consider how to generate permutations of a given number. You can use a recursive approach or an iterative approach to generate all possible arrangements of the digits of the number.
Think about how to check if a number formed by a permutation is self-divisible. You will need to iterate over each digit of the number and check the divisibility condition.
Remember to handle cases where digits might be zero. A digit of zero will make any number formed by that permutation non-self-divisible since division by zero is undefined.
When generating permutations, ensure that you do not count duplicates. For example, if the number has repeating digits, you should avoid counting those permutations multiple times.
Consider using a set to store the unique permutations. This will help you automatically handle duplicates that arise from repeated digits.
Think about the efficiency of your solution. Generating all permutations can be computationally expensive, especially for larger numbers. Aim to optimize your approach.
Once you have the unique permutations, iterate through them and count how many of them are self-divisible. This will be your final answer.
Make sure to return the count of self-divisible permutations as your output. Consider what data type you will use to store this count.
Finally, ensure that you test your solution with edge cases, such as numbers with all the same digits, numbers with zeros, and very small numbers like 1 or 2.

questionNotes: The input is a positive integer, and you need to consider all its digit permutations.
Self-divisible numbers cannot have zero as any of their digits.
You must count unique permutations only.
Return the total count of self-divisible permutations.
